Original Message:

Newsgroup:  comp.ai.neural-nets

Joe Legris wrote:
> 
> Ben Park wrote:
> > Are the digits of Pi predictable?
> >
> > What if you train a neural network to do the job?
Will you get a total failure?
> 
> They are completely predictable if you are in
possession of the
> algorithm for computing Pi to an arbitrary number of
digits.
> 
> (see
http://www.faqs.org/faqs/sci-math-faq/specialnumbers/computePi/
)
> 
> If you are willing to concede that a human nervous
system is essentially
> a large neural network, then teaching a human to
compute Pi is training
> a neural network to predict Pi.

I think you have suggested a very interesting problem
here.  The common neural networks have no RAM
capability and cannot be trained to execute a typical
computational algorithm.  I doubt if there is an
algorithm to compute Pi without the use of scratchpad
memory.  OTOH, a recurrent ANN is theoretically
capable of performing such a computation, although
there are very few examples of this. (My 4Play program
is one such example.)  The problem is how to train
such a network. I don't think there is any way to use
backprop for such a problem.  Neuroevolution might
work, which is the method I use.  I will put this on
my list of possible projects!

A recurrent ANN is also capable of generating a
sequence of outputs, which is what is needed in this
case.  You want to just start it going, and then it
outputs 3, then 1, then 4, etc., with no further input.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
